awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Sea ice as a driver of Antarctic benthic macroalgal community composition and nearshore trophic connectivity
awd_abstract_narration:
The western Antarctic Peninsula has become a model for understanding cold water communities and how they may be changing in Antarctica and elsewhere. Brown macroalgae (seaweeds) form extensive undersea forests in the northern portion of this region where they play a key role in providing both physical structure and a food (carbon) source for shallow water communities. Yet between Anvers Island (64 degrees S latitude) and Adelaide Island (67 S latitude) these macroalgae become markedly less abundant and diverse. This is probably because the habitat to the south is covered by more sea ice for a longer period, and the sea ice reduces the amount of light that reaches the algae. The reduced macroalgal cover undoubtedly impacts other organisms in the food web, but the ways in which it alters sea-floor community processes and organization is unknown. This project will quantitatively document the macroalgal communities at multiple sites between Anvers and Adelaide Islands using a combination of SCUBA diving, video surveys, and algal collections. Sea ice cover, light levels, and other environmental parameters on community structure will be modelled to determine which factors have the largest influence. Impacts on community structure, food webs, and carbon flow will be assessed through a mixture of SCUBA diving and video surveys. Broader impacts include the training of graduate students and a postdoctoral researcher, as well as numerous informal public education activities including lectures, presentations to K-12 groups, and a variety of social media-based outreach.

Macroalgal communities are more abundance and diverse to the north along the Western Antarctic Peninsula, perhaps due to the greater light availability that is associated with shorter period of sea-ice cover. This project will determine the causes and community level consequence of this variation in algal community structure. First, satellite data on sea ice extent and water turbidity will be used to select study sites between 64 S and 69 S where the extent of annual sea ice cover is the primary factor influencing subsurface light levels. Then, variations in macroalgal cover across these study sites will be determined by video line-transect surveys conducted by SCUBA divers. The health, growth, and physiological status of species found at the different sites will be determined by quadrat sampling. The relative importance of macroalgal-derived carbon to the common invertebrate consumers in the foodweb will be assessed with stable isotope and fatty acid biomarker techniques. This will reveal how variation in macroalgal abundance and species composition across the sea ice cover gradient impacts sea floor community composition and carbon flow throughout the food web. In combination, this work will facilitate predictions of how the ongoing reductions in extent and duration of sea ice cover that is occurring in the region as a result of global climate change will impact the structure of nearshore benthic communities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project addressed two of the research hypotheses of the Sea ice as a driver of Antarctic benthic macroalgal community composition and nearshore trophic connectivity project that examined the relationship between sea ice cover and macroalgal cover. Specifically, it sought to determine (1) whether the north-south gradient in macroalgal cover within the 64?- 69? S latitude study area was correlated with annual irradiance differences caused by annual sea ice coverage patterns that govern light availability to the macroalgae and (2) whether the patterns of macroalgal cover could be predicted based on sea ice cover patterns as determined by satellite images.

 It has been known since the early 1900s that macroalgal forests dominate shallow hard bottom areas along the northern portion of the western Antarctic Peninsula (WAP). Qualitative studies have documented that macroalgal biomass and diversity decrease south of Anvers Island at 64?S. It has been hypothesized that these observed decreases resulted from decreased light levels caused by increasing annual sea ice cover towards the south.

This project assisted in sampling site selection by providing remote sensing derived information on sea ice concentrations and turbidity prior to the R/V Laurence M. Gould research cruise in April and May of 2019. In the end, fifteen sites were sampled across a strong gradient in annual sea ice concentrations. For each site, macroalgal cover at depths ≤ 40 m was determined through analysis of the collected video transects collected by scientific diving. Scientific divers also collected macroalgae, macroinvertebrates and mesoinvertebrates to answer the collaborative project?s other research questions.

 The project also used publicly available remote sensing derived sea ice concentrations from several sources (Sea Ice Index, National Ice Charts, and AMSR2) to create mean annual and summer (October-February) sea ice concentrations for the period 2014-2019. This averaging period was selected as it is thought to correspond to the lifespan of many of the important macroalgae species under study. The project also used Geographic Information Systems (GIS) to model global solar irradiance across the study area.

 This project found that fleshy macroalgal cover is indeed strongly, negatively correlated with both annual and summer sea ice concentrations. The impact on these relative differences in sea ice concentrations on incoming radiation are much larger than the 10% difference in modeled average daily horizontal daily solar irradiance among the sites.

 Documenting a strong linear relationship between sea ice concentrations and macroalgae along this portion of the WAP is important. It suggests that the observed changes in sea ice cover over the historical 40-year passive microwave sea ice record could have caused commensurate changes in the macroalgal communities at sites that currently have low to moderate macroalgae cover. Similarly, even small (15%) projected future decreases in sea ice concentrations along the WAP could substantially increase macroalgae cover in locations where ice cover is currently high.

 A broader impact of this project has been to improve and diversify the STEM workforce. It offered an undergraduate research opportunity emphasizing geospatial analysis that trained a student planning on entering the Geospatial workforce as a GIS Analyst.
